lines.text: Okay, real talk—tipping here still feels kinda wild to me.
Right? It’s everywhere now. Like… even for coffee.
And you feel guilty if you don’t, which is the weird part.
But I also get it—wages are messed up, so people rely on it.
Exactly. It’s less a bonus and more… mandatory.
Yeah, it turns into this whole unspoken rule thing.
And it’s tied to fairness too—who should carry the cost?
It’s funny how we normalize broken systems.
Yeah… and it changes how you see people, too.

cutins.prompt: カットインして会話を広げろ（流れを乱すな）

choices.text: Totally. I’m still trying to figure out what’s ‘normal’ here—when is tipping actually expected?
Yeah tipping is weird. Anyway, everything’s getting expensive these days.
I get it, but tipping shouldn’t exist. It’s objectively wrong.
Same, I just do 20% no matter what so I don’t have to think about it.

cutins.prompt: 価値観に一段深く入れ（重くしすぎるな）

choices.text: So it’s like culture is patching a broken system—kind of a weird definition of ‘normal,’ right?
Culture differences are interesting. I visited Japan once.
Honestly, people should just tip more and stop complaining.
I’m okay with it, but I wish the rules were clearer—what counts as ‘fair’ for everyone?
